ranked_diseases.explanation: Stargardt Disease, a form of juvenile macular degeneration, is characterized by reduced visual acuity, retinal pigment epithelial mottling, and abnormal electroretinogram, matching the patient's features.
Retinitis Pigmentosa can present with reduced visual acuity and abnormal electroretinogram. Although pigment epithelial mottling is less classical, it is a potential feature in atypical cases.
Best Disease often presents with abnormal electroretinogram and retinal changes. The presence of reduced visual acuity and retinal pigment epithelial mottling aligns well with this condition.
Cone-Rod Dystrophies can manifest with reduced visual acuity and an abnormal electroretinogram. Retinal pigment changes are also seen, although typically more severe.
